folder: 17th Street and Union Square East, Manhattan, N.Y.
text:
Celebrations, Parades.: Reviewing stand and crowds watching parade at 17th Street and Union Square, East. Foreground Broadway streetcar-Franchise in 1885 according to New York Times note car rails on 17th Street, also fire engines approaching on 17th Street. St. Georges P.E. Church opposite, Livingston Place, North west corner 16th Street erected 1849 hat twin spires were replaced after because of fire. This is in celebration of Decoration Day.

Galloway N.Y.

About 1895
title: Celebrations - Parades - Municipal events - Decoration Day Parade.

text:
THE NEW HOME OF THE SOCIETY OF TAMMANY

Now being erected on Union Square, New York City, not far from the Hall on Fourteenth Street which has been Tammany's headquarters for sixty years

Photograph by Wide World Photos

August 1928
title: Manhattan: Union Square (East) - 17th Street (East).

text:
(1)
42 Union Square East and clearing on the S.E. corner of 17th Street, site of 44 Union Square and the Westmoreland apartment house (100 East 17th Street), which have been demolished to make room for the new Tammany Hall. Part of the Guardian Life Insurance Building and the old houses 105-17 East 17th Street, on the north side of 17th Street, are shown across the clearing. The date is in the third year of Mayor James J. Walker's first term.
July 7, 1928.
P. L. Sperr.

(2)
42 Union Square East and the new Tammany Hall, at S.E. corner of 17th Street. The date is Election Day in what would have been the fourth and last year of Mayor James J. Walker's second term. Mayor O'Brien, elected the previous November to fill out the last year of Walker's term, was defeated by the Republican - Fusion candidate [Fiorello] La Guardia. A rough and bitter contest at the polls is going on as this picture is taken.
November 7, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.

Stamp of The New York Public Library, Astor Lenox and Tilden Foundations.
title: Manhattan: Union Square (East) - 17th Street (East).

title: Manhattan: Union Square (East) - 17th Street (East).

text:
Union Square East (normally 4th Avenue) at E. 17th Street as photographed northeastward from various points. No. 1 is from the diagonal far corner of the Square, at Broadway and 14th Street; No. 2 from atop an office structure on the same street and No. 3 from inside the Park. Occupying the various corners at this point are, the Everett Building, the Guardian Life Insurance Co. Building and Tammany Hall. Incidentally, Fourth Avenue, officially starts there and that portion bordering the Square is identified by same.

The Lincoln statue appears in the earlier view. This is at the Broadway point, popularly known as "Death Curve." This arose from the danger to pedestrians from the speeding Broadway streetcars on their turn into 14th Street from Union Square West.

View 1: February 12, 1928 Neg No. 221
View 2: August 4, 1930 Neg No 221
View 3: February 24, 1933

P. L. Sperr
title: Manhattan: Union Square (East) - 17th Street (East).

title: Manhattan: Union Square (East) - 17th Street (East).

text:
The new Tammany Hall, Union Square East at the S.E. corner of 17th Street, newly erected on the site of the old Westmoreland Apartments (originally Hotel), which occupied the site from about 1877 to 1928. The bank is about to move into the ground floor. In the background may be seen the tower of the new Consolidated Gas and New York Edison Building, recently completed on 14th Street on the site of the old Tammany Hall and the Academy of Music.

The Society of St. Tammany, or Columbian Order, was founded in Philadelphia and spread through New England, before a New York City chapter was established in 1789. It was originally a benevolent organization, and first identified itself with politics in the presidential campaign of 1800, when, under the leadership of Vice-Presidential candidate Aaron Burr, it supported the Jefferson-Burr ticket. The first Tammany Hall, built in 1801, stood on Frankfort and Nassau Streets. On July 4, 1868, the second Hall on 14th Street was opened with the Democratic National Convention of that year. In 1928 it moved into the present building.

The Tammany Hall General Committee, with which it is practically identical in membership, has for a long time been in control of the Democratic Party in New York County, at times almost to the point of complete identification with it. This picture, for instance, is taken near the height of Mayor James J. Walker's popularity, the spring preceding his re-election. Tammany Hall is not only identified with the Party in Manhattan, but is working harmoniously with the leaders of the other four boroughs.

May, 1929.

Ewing Galloway.
title: Manhattan: Union Square (East) - 17th Street (East).

text:
Tammany Hall, Union Square East at S.E. corner of 17th Street, the ground floor occupied by a branch of the Manufacturers Trust Company. The new Tammany Hall is four years old, as pictured here. At the time it was built, the store of 42 Union Square, adjoining, was occupied by Flaxman Woolen,
Incorporated.
March 25, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same, Election Day of that year, when, for the first time in twenty years, the Tammany candidates for Mayor, Comptroller, and Aldermanic President were all defeated. But the Borough President and four candidates for County Offices, whose names
follow the first three, were elected.
The building in the background, with the "Hyman -- Human -- " sign is not shown in this view because of the angle of the camera.
November 7, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.
title: Manhattan: Union Square (East) - 17th Street (East).

title: Manhattan: Union Square (East) - 17th Street (East).

text:
(1 & 2)

Communist Demonstration: The May Day Paraders disbanding on Union Square East at 17th Street. Note Tammany Hall (right) at the S.E. corner of same. This is a set of 2 views.

May 1, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.

(3)

An eastward view across the crowded Square. Photographers vantage point is on East 16th Street, slightly west of Union Square West (Broadway).

May 1, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Celebrations - Parades - Municipal Events - Communist Demonstration.

text:
Union Square East (Fourth Avenue), at the S. E. corner of East 17th Street (left), showing the building housing the Columbian Order, better known as Tammany Hall.

1940

George D. Chinn
title: Manhattan: Union Square (East) - 17th Street (East).
